In Chinese culture, there is a saying: "ä¸‰åè€Œç«‹", which means that by the age of 30, a person should have established their career, family, and moral principles. This stage of life signifies financial stability and independence, allowing a person to stand on their own. 

I only have a few months until I turn 30, and I am still trying to understand myselfâ€”figuring out my strengths and weaknesses and finding my true path, something I both somewhat enjoy and am good at. Five years ago, I finally made the move to transition my career, and I am so glad I did. Since then, life has had its ups and downs, and sometimes things havenâ€™t worked out due to my knowledge, abilities, personality or other reasons. But I have no regrets. I always believe that every decision I make is the best one possible given the circumstances at the time. I always strive to do my best in everything I undertake in the present moment. Sometimes, things don't work out because simply it wasnâ€™t meant for me.

Nowadays, I often hear people on the internet praise the idea of **"inner stability."** They say that true strength comes from within and that without it, we are left with only *internal friction*â€”something we must put an end to. However, over time, I've come to realize that stopping this internal friction often means sacrificing our sensitivity. I find myself caught in this paradox:<br>

### About [PTSD]...

Sometime between 2017 and 2019, I had a major accident alone in Sydney. Funny enough, I usually remember the exact date of significant life events, but since I forced myself to **try to** erase this one from my memory, I eventually managed to forget the date. Ironically, though, while the date is erased, every detail of the event still lingers in my mind.

I remember blood everywhere. I remember people calling an ambulanceâ€”and how it took forever to arrive because they got lost. I remember feeling cold, shivering. I remember the countless morphine injections. I remember the hopelessness of lying on that hospital bed (didn't even want to know which hospital I am at), waiting for surgery. Doctors and nurses came to me one by one, introducing themselves before disappearing again. I remember them asking, *"Do you have anyone to accompany you to surgery?"* And I said no. I remember being told, over and over, how lucky I wasâ€”how I had nearly lost my leg if I got hit just 1 cm further-Yes, thatâ€™s also one of the conversations I desperately want to erase. But I canâ€™t.

After the surgery, everything felt surreal. Every morning when I woke up, I couldnâ€™t believe it wasnâ€™t just a bad dreamâ€”that it had really happened. I struggled to do even the simplest things alone. Going to the toilet, doing housework, taking a showerâ€”every task felt like an uphill battle. I had to learn how to walk again. It took more than half a year's struggle before I could do basic exercises and bend my knee properly. Every time I felt hopeless, my parents would comfort me, reminding me how fortunate I wasâ€”that I hadnâ€™t lost my leg or become disabled. They said it so often that I started to feel guilty for still being depressed. **So many people have far worse accidents than meâ€”why couldnâ€™t I just be grateful?** I lost many friends during that time. Not because I wanted to push them away, but because I didnâ€™t want to sound like a victim. Yet at the same time, I wasnâ€™t strong enough to pretend I was okay.

Even after five or six years, now that I am much calmer, I can finally write down this story for the first timeâ€”calmly, without crying. But the ever-present pain of the scar still reminds me of what I went through. And every time the physiotherapist massages my knee during a session, I still feel sick to my stomach. I often find myself avoiding anything that carries even the slightest riskâ€”too many forms of exercise, even drivingâ€”because I just don't feel safe. Every new pain, every "failure," feels like another blow, hitting me harder each time.

A month ago, I reunited with an old friend of mine. She was my best friend in primary school, but we lost touch after going to different schools. She has always been one of the incredibly smart kids (which was later confirmed when she took an IQ test and scored high). I, on the other hand, could only achieve average grades no matter how hard I tried, while she effortlessly excelled in tests. Later, I heard she got into her dream schoolâ€”Carnegie Mellon University in the U.S.â€”to study computer science. But then, she suddenly developed severe eye floaters and lost her central vision in both eyes. She had no choice but to drop out and spend a year in an eye hospital. After countless desperate days and nights, multiple treatments, and surgeries, she finally regained her eyesight. She then decided to move to Adelaide, Australia, seeking a more balanced and less stressful life compared to the U.S. Because of that, we were able to reunite from time to time.

I can sense that she is a bit *different* from others in the way she thinks and behaves. Surprisingly, I found that we share some of the same unusual thoughts and behaviors. There are many things Iâ€™ve felt *ashamed* to share with othersâ€”some of which I admit are somewhat unhealthy and that Iâ€™ve been trying so hard to improve. But the way she speaks about them so naturally gave me a sense of reassurance and strength. She seems completely at ease with everything that comes her way, yet she still fights against this cruel world in her own unique way. On one hand, Iâ€™m happy to have found someone who truly understands and shares the same thoughts as me. On the other, I see a different possibility: **maybe I donâ€™t always have to overcome everything. If I canâ€™t change certain things, perhaps I can learn to live with themâ€”while still living earnestly and fully**.

### About [Carer Transition]...

About five years ago, I finally made the move to transition from a non-quantitative background to a more quantitative career. Thanks to my partnerâ€”whom I met in 2019â€”his encouragement pushed me to step out of my comfort zone and try out new things. At that time, I felt like I had half given up on life, struggling to overcome PTSD while stuck in a job I hated. 

However, I never imagined that I would embark on this quantitative journey. With a bachelor's degree in pharmacy, my options for a masterâ€™s degree were quite limited. Initially, I pursued a Master of Public Health, but halfway through, I found myself increasingly drawn to statistics and programming. That was when I came across a new masterâ€™s program at UNSWâ€”**Master of Health Data Science**â€”specifically designed for those with a health or medical background, even without prior experience in quantitative analysis or programming. I decided to take a leap of faith and give it a try.

Iâ€™ve never told my lecturer this, but it was one of his coursesâ€”**Statistical Modelling**â€”that solidified my determination to continue this path. As someone without any formal quantitative training, who often felt like I was *losing the will to live* whenever I encountered mathematical equations, learning quantitative concepts through statistical software was very helpful starting point. I never told him directly, but I believe I once sent him an email after the course ended, thanking him for "opening the world of statistics to me".

I consider myself very lucky because I believe that 60â€“70% of my efforts have been rewarded in the end. Many times, hard work doesnâ€™t lead to any recognition or results, so I feel incredibly fortunate and grateful that, so far, every project Iâ€™ve embarked on has had tangible outcomes. Even though some (or most) of my past works to date may not have been of good quality, that doesnâ€™t bother me. What matters is that Iâ€™ve poured my heart and soul into every project, and Iâ€™m grateful for the opportunity to learn and growâ€”slowly but steadilyâ€”over time.

However, I have to say that the biggest challenge for someone without formal quantitative training is the lack of abstract, logical, systematic, and step-by-step thinking. This is the most noticeable difference Iâ€™ve observed between non-quantitative and quantitative individuals. Itâ€™s not just in researchâ€”quantitative thinkers tend to approach even the simplest life questions with a structured, logical, step-by-step mindset. 

Iâ€™ve never tried to hide the fact that Iâ€™m not a very logical person. As a *Perceiving* type in the MBTI personality framework, I often do things without a plan and tend to jump from one thing to another. This often makes me wonder whether being an analyst is truly the right path for me. Despite that, Iâ€™m deeply grateful for every opportunity that has come my way and for the chance to keep learning. Through all of lifeâ€™s ups and downs, I have never stopped discovering myself and searching for my true path.
